segments.text: civilians.
Some of the civilians were World War II physically disabled paratroopers, you know, that type of thing.
But we had some civilians that had never been in the military.
Was your friend right that it was a dead end?
No.
That was one of the most interesting three years I'd ever spent.
Official reports were, in fact, I was recommended for general officer by the
by my boss and his boss, and then we had a retired General Jeff Ballmer, who's deceased now.
He too gave me a plug, so.
The tour was cut short because I went to, was selected for the War College.
Now, during this time, Allen Dulles was in charge of the CIA.
Did you have any work with him?
Yep.
Could you describe him?
Tell me about him.
What kind of relations did you have with Mr. Dulles?
He was a real character.
Interesting, colorful character, I mean.
When I say character, I usually mean a positive rather than a colorful character.
Deep voice, talked loud, laughed a lot.
I remember one time we were having an exercise, which we used to have in the government.
We don't do it anymore.
On evacuation war, you know, evacuations.
Of course, they will get back around to that pretty soon.
And we were having this exercise out in the area and so in our scenario we had a situation that we had written for Fabricate Fiction of what could happen and some of the personalities involved
their reaction, like some of them would get killed and so forth, take on like that.
And old Allen Dulles, I don't know how much he knows or experienced, he's had wargaming action, that's what this is, with civilians seldom ever do.
He really got a kick.

He was just coming by to visit, but he got so involved with that, he wanted to sit down and listen to the whole thing, and then return and say, by the way, whatever happened, just like it actually was in process, whatever happened to so-and-so.
Was he a good leader?
Yeah, I think so.
Of course, his advantage was he had such prestige on the national level, see, with his brother being Secretary of State, and the two men, Eisenhower, I thought, was very close to him.
He had a sister, too, that was a real strong individual, which I never did know her.
She was involved in a lot of diplomatic action in Europe.
Was there a lot of, I should say, how did the Secretary of State and the CIA Director, how did they get along together?
What were the relations between the CIA and the State Department?
Well, you aren't talking about the two brothers.
You're talking about any Secretary of State.
No, I'm just talking about what the relations were with the CIA.
and the State Department during the time that you were there?
Oh, during?
Yeah.
I think they're very good.
You see, because, see, he's the director of Central Intelligence.
Sure.
Which includes, see, the State Department's got an intelligence department, and, of course, the services plus the defense intelligence.
And, uh...
I never, I wasn't aware of any friction at all between us.
Because we had, we had joint groups at work.
I've already forgotten the name now, but nearly every operation that'd be planned, not all of them, there'd be certain ones that probably wouldn't, but any one of them,
national significance would be worked out and cleared in this particular working group of CIA, state, and the defense that represented them.

And you obviously haven't necessarily because all of them have other plans and you can really foul up things royally if you get somebody that's going splashing around in some environment where somebody else has made plans and is working with them.
But there was never any competition, nor was there any at that time when I was there, as I was aware of.
They thought that the CIA was running their own national policy.
The Bay of Pigs, of course, came along.
That wasn't while I was there.
That came in 61, but there were a couple of interesting incidents that happened.
One was the invasion, the Soviet invasion of Hungary in 1956 when you were there.
Do you remember that?
I mean, what was the CIA's response to that?
And did you have to have war plans for that?
No.
Our war plans were coordinating our U.S. assets, military, which obviously we don't have in Hungary, we don't have in Poland.
Right, okay.

with no i don't i don't worry i guess i recall more reading the papers than anything else hungry what about that it just seemed it seemed as i recall back in those days not from the cia knowledge but uh cia might have been involved in that we had we had led the
Hungarians to believe that we might come to their aid if they resisted.
And I think that was all based on the propaganda on the radio, whether it was the CIA's radio, whether it was our information program, and then we didn't produce.
Right.
What about Lebanon?
Eisenhower sending the troops in?
Well, I was in Europe then.
And how about the problems with, the problems that were growing with Laos and especially Vietnam?
I wasn't involved in that.
I mean, in CIA I wasn't.
Later on I was, because not only was it the military,
recommended against us, any involvement.
And the same thing we did in Korea, the same thing we did in Vietnam.
Did you enjoy working with the CIA?
Yeah.
What did you do?
And I found those Ivy League people that they talked about.
You see, like we talked about other things in combat, perceiving things.
Now, this individual here, probably he was, the problem was, like we met the enemy and
He is us, you know.
I think that individual was a problem.

He couldn't get along with these people, see, and so he views them as being the villains rather than himself because, no, I was working with Helms, you know, who later on was the, he was a real fine guy and easy to get along with.
I found just the opposite of it.
What else?
Was there anything that struck you about Helms, the type of person he was?
He was a smooth operator.
What do you mean?
He was a real sophisticated individual, a debonair.
Both he and his wife were very impressive individuals.
He's a cultured lady.
In other words, he moves very well in high society.
At first, he was head of the Condescension Service, the CDI.
This character has just been fired.
And he worked very well with Dulles.
Of course, Dulles was over, as you know, CIA is divided in two.
You've got D.D.
Allen and Kolesnick, and then you have the other, which is overt intelligence, where you have all the scientists and guys like you, you know, who really study all of this.
They can tell you everything about agriculture and each of the, any part of the USSR, what's happening in Siberia, and oil, although some say their oil estimate was incorrect.
It seems to me scientific.
They may really have a tremendous talent.
That's the thing that impressed me when I got to CIA.
How do you attract this type of talent?
I'm talking about now intellectual talent.
So I can see, they say, I believe, obviously, a lot from Harvard.
intrigued, I think, some of these people for this type of work, particularly the research, the scientific point, which, of course, enables these to write papers.
Of course, they're classified, but it's a lot of personal satisfaction.
What opinion did you have?
And you're sort of alluding to this now, but I'd like to answer on this.
And that is, your opinion of the top level civilian bureaucrats at the CIA
What did you think of them?
When I was there, I thought they were tops because they were selected on ability.
See, like Heldner, he was a career man.
He had been there for years, so he knew everything about it.
But when you pull in a political appointee, like this recent disaster, like I saw a cartoon today, they asked him questions about, yes, I'm a friend with the president.
And what else you did?
Well, my company made paper clips of it.
They said, fine, and you're qualified to be at the CIA.
And Dulles, of course, was more of a political appointee.
However, he'd been in the business for years.
He goes all the way back to World War II.
And he'd been in Washington.
He knew his way around in Washington.

I think it was a big mistake, and Stansfield Turner, for example, he's a very capable Navy admiral and that sort of thing, but he tried to organize CIA like the Navy, and you can't do that, and you can't deal with these, I call them Ivy League, and I don't, Ivy League got a lot from California, from Caltech, but you can't expect them to respond
to you if you treat everybody as if they're a military organization.
So basically you had a high opinion of the bureaucrats.
Yeah.
But not a very high opinion of many of the political appointments.
That's right.
It comes in.
Because it shows.
If you have time to teach them, you know, I own the job training.
But see, they've run into all these people all over.
My friend, who I can't remember his name, I'll talk about that when we get to the joint staff.
He became head of CIA, and he was a career man.
But they accused him of being too honest.
He went to Congress and told them all about everything.
In the long run, he probably helped CIA more doing that than getting up there and trying to double talk and say, well, I'm just not free to discuss this.
But he's no longer there.
Of course, he's appalled by what's happening in the CIA.
Because it becomes just like a family, as I say.
What's his name?
Maybe I'll think of it later on.
I can't think of it now.
What was he?
He's a previous...
He followed Hale.
He's before Turner, really.
Do you remember who that was?
No, he was quit.
He was free.
Yeah, because Carter changed him, you know, because after all he'd been there during the Nixon years.
Now in 1958 you left the CIA and went to the Army War College.
What was your opinion of that college?
Well, of course, I'm a little biased to be in the Army.
I thought it was a real fine.
Because it enabled you, to begin with, there's no examination.
This is the year that you go there to think, to study.
The only requirement is that you must write a thesis.
And it has to be a thesis.
And it has been accepted.
I never did submit mine, but it has been accepted for a master's degree, of course, if you do the other subject.
But the problem is that most of them are classified, so they have to be rewritten to declassify them, or they have to wait several years.
And so that, too, is very interesting because, as any thesis is supposed to be, is an original creative thing where you really research it.
And so it's
really interesting to do the research.
Of course, you have to do that all during the academic year, so most of that's done at night.
So it's not an easy course at all.
But it's national strategy.
This is a place you have an opportunity to relate weaponry with economy, economics.
So at the end, you should have, and you use them.
A lot of civilians come in.
And at the end, we have a national seminar where you bring in all these people from Washington, the Secretary of State, a whole range of them.
The Secretary of State, of course, doesn't have time to participate, but you have people who participate in that seminar, but you also have some guest speakers
I guess you'd call that an enrichment program.
They come and add to and agree or disagree with what the national seminar has come up as a national strategy for the direction we should be going.
Is it feasible?
Is it attainable?
And all that.
An entire year is moved along in that way, which is supposed to result in a product
that's qualified and eligible to move at the highest level of government, whether it be state, CIA, national defense.
And you have students.
We have CIA there.
We have State Department there.
We have Army and Navy, Marine.
The USIA, they usually have one there, informational.
I've often heard that the war colleges are almost mandatory for one to be promoted to generalship.
That's pretty good.
There have been some promoted, but you'd have to look a long while.
And that's the reason why the career ladder is a lot being written about that now in our periodicals.

those who it has to really do for the 20-year retirement which is critical now because it's very costly and then you get into the double dippers why does a person get out after 20 years at 20 years of course he gets half his retirement is half of his base pay he's still young enough to get another job some got another job in government
So they become what they call double-dippers, see?
Although he can't draw all of his other pay, there's a limit.
He gets about half of it, something like that.
I'm not aware of it.
I've not been following that.
Well, why do they retire?
I've just told you that I'm going to say what you've already concluded in court.
But that time, if they haven't been to the Armed Forces Staff College or the Army War College or the
Naval War College, National War College, or the Air Force.
We have Army going to all of those, you know, the same as Navy.
And they all have the same equipment as far as credit is concerned.
Then they feel that they're not going to, their chances of making general officer, even those who go, the chances of making general officer.
I look at my classmate.
We had 200 in my class, and I think we had, uh,
10 who made general loss in that class.
Some classes go as high as 20, some as low as 5 or something.
Another reason why the Army has never discouraged that is because many of those who stay in for 20 years are non-regular and we need them and they're very capable and they're good.
We certainly don't want to expand our regular Army to
And then find out later on you've got a contractor, a constrictor.
So it appeals to them.
They stand for 20 years.
And do you think that it prepared you for a general officer slot?
I mean, did it give you the type of education that a general officer should have?
I think so.
See the two of your students.
Just like I had been to CIA and worked with them.
Many of your students have been in the Pentagon, and they bring a lot of experience to that that shares with others who may not have operated at that level, see.
And some are real good writers.
In fact, we have a problem with that.
They only have about 15 to 20 minutes to go in there and write their position, you know.
And you have some who experience that, boy, they just sit down and gifted writers
that can put concepts and ideas together on the first draft.
Well, I couldn't do that, but I could learn a lot from their approach to it.
And you get all these together, sharing, and I say it's the end of the year.
It's really been a fun experience for me.
And I agree that it does, certainly.
I thought I was better prepared after that if I were to be selected.

I didn't think I was ever going to be selected for colonel, I didn't mention that, but in Iran, having not been in Korea when I went there on a staff visit for a month, and all these other people, you know, that really had gone through a lot.
But I was selected for it, and I couldn't believe it when the sergeant came in and said, sir, you're on the colonel's list.
And now still, after graduating from the War College,
I hadn't been to Korea, and the chances are with all these other outstanding officers.
See, the problem is, what system?
How can you possibly select, say, 50 a year?
That's about what we got in the Army.
50 a year out of all those qualified colonels.
That's where luck comes into it a lot, because they all have outstanding efficiency reports.
Because I've been on boards selecting...
Selecting majors to lieutenant colonels.
And I'm telling you, you go through all those records, and you've got to come up with a limited number.
And you really do a lot of soul searching.
Of course, you have a team.
They all look at it, and they all vote what it amounts to.
You know, what do you vote this or not?
Then you have to come back and work at it again.
And it is really a difficult job.
And at one time, it used to be selecting by name, like a
Like we talked about, General Marshall practically selected all of the division commanders by name.
It isn't that way now.
Colonel to Brigadier General is strictly by record with this group working on it.
There's no doubt it helps you if you happen to have somebody that you served under and he says, oh, I know this individual here.
He is really top notch.
He might have an advantage over another, but they said, well, he's got an outstanding record, but I don't know if any of you know him.
No, but I say, I know this guy here who raided him, and I know the type of raider he is, and if he says he's good, then he is.
Well, for the War College, you want to go to the next one?
Yeah, in 1958, then you went to Fort Riley, Kansas.
Right.
What was your job there?
Once again, career management came to the Army War College like they did at the Armed Forces Staff College.
Before the end of the course, I would call them prima donnas.
They're all jockeying for position, you know, because everybody's in the running, you know.
All the students are jockeying for position?
Well, some of them, you know, for assignments because, you know, the next one is very, very important.
Sure.
And they want to be with troops.
You've got to command, see.
command the unit.
That's another thing along with the school.
So these guys were going to the Pentagon because they all had contacts there, you know, checking on it.
They'd come back and say, yeah, it looks like I'm going to get a command.
They asked me, and I said, no, I don't know.
Well, haven't you been there?
No, I haven't been there.
But chances are I won't get one.
But I'll go ahead and let the chips fall.
So here comes
General Ben Harold, who headed the career management that I had served with at Fort Benning in Italy, really.
He's a third division.
So he came up, and I hadn't even talked to him, but I spoke to him.
And so he named off those who got command.
And he says, Colonel Andrews to the first division at Fort Raleigh, command Johnson.
And my friends all came around the end, and he said,
Rascal, you knew this all this time, and you was keeping us quiet.
I said, no, I didn't have a clue.
I'm as surprised as you are.
And some of them didn't get their command.
So I went to Fort Riley, and I was assigned as the commanding officer of the 1st Battle Group 18th Infantry.
Yet at the time, a colonel who was going to become chief of staff didn't want to leave the 18th, and the generals supported him, so I took command of the division trains.
What does that mean, division trains?
They're the support, the supporting division, you know, the quartermaster and all of that.
You have the combat arms and then you have all of the support division.
Now, at that organization, at that time, they were called division trains.
So I stayed there for about
A couple of months, I guess, before.
And that was good experience because that gave me an opportunity to work for the services.
I've been infantry all my life.
Then I took the first battle group.
And the reason why I was due for an overseas assignment, so that's the reason I got this, because the 1st Division, at least the 1st Battle Group, 18th Infantry, was going to move to Germany.
And they had a program called Gyroscope.
We were supposed to replace a battle group in Germany, and that battle group would come back to Raleigh in the 1st Division, and we would go to the 8th Division.
That was Operation Charter School.
Yeah, that's what they called Charter School.
So we trained there.
And the battle group was terrific, and not because of me, although, of course, I'd like to think I was a brilliant leader that did it.
But we trained our own recruits, and our take of these young men
Came from California.
Most of them just out of high school.
They hadn't been contaminated by anybody else.
Hadn't been called, you know, like they do in most training centers to recruit.
You know, they pick out the higher IQ types.
They go to one place and they call through them.
And then sometimes I say contaminate them.
They get them, the training is wrong.
You'll have a really receptive young man.
He becomes bitter because of the way he's been treated.
But we didn't have it.
We got it at Fort Riley, right out of high school.
Some of them had finished college.
Some had two years of college and decided, even though that maybe they could.
See, this was before Vietnam.
But they decided that they would fulfill their obligation.
Really tough.
We trained them.
Every bit of the training they had, we gave it to them.
And then we took them to Europe.
And they were receptive, for example.
There's always a big drive on to purchase a savings bond.
And I appealed to these young men.
I said, now, you'll be in two years.
You might as well save this money, because a lot of you are going to college or finishing college.
And this will be saved.
And that's the best advice I can give you, because you'll be assured of this amount of money.
They signed up 100%.
It is the size of the battle group.
Let me see now, we had five come in, around 1,200 men.
Did you, what did you think about being a commander?
This is really the first time that you ever got a group like this, did you?
Well, of course, I commanded a battalion in World War II.
But I mean the first peacetime.
And of course, this was larger in numbers than the battalion.
Well, of course, I was thrilled.
Everybody, I shouldn't say everybody, most Army types of these,
Well, it's the same thing in the Navy.
The Navy wants the command of a ship, and the Air Force wants the command of a squadron, you know, where you run your...
It's the biggest thrill is what you strive for, to command, to have a unit of your own, and working with the officers, and having them to respond to you.
And it's the highest-rated corps in that battle group, 18th Infantry.
It has a long history.
It's one of the oldest units.
in the Army.
So it was a high spree to court when I got there, so I'm not the one who bolted and built and shooted up.
Of course, they were understrength, and so most of our, and those who weren't eligible to go overseas, they transferred out.
So basically, we had non-commissioned officers and officers, and we brought in these recruits and trained them.
So it's really our unit.
We didn't get a bunch of transfer, you know, the troublemakers.
Were there major problems?
No.
Not at all.
Some of the other units, yes.
So we moved, well, I'll give you a problem, yes.
They publicized the gyroscope program.
And so some of the
sergeants that we got transferred in to become part of the gyroscope.
They had married German girls in Germany.
So the German girls, of course, wanted to go back to Germany.
This was their opportunity.
And many of them had a very unfortunate experience in the United States because then mixed marriages, you know, at that time you still, anybody on TV couldn't
couldn't kiss, for example, like they do now, you know, like a guest on a tour.
And so to be married, and unfortunately some of these were southern blacks, in some states it's against the law, you know.
They're actually, they couldn't even live there.
They lived there, they got arrested.
So this gave them an opportunity to go home.
Yet we didn't have space for them.
In other words, we were overstrength and we were only going to ship out with the
our signs, our authorized strength, T-O-N-E.
So it meant some of those weren't going to be able to travel with us, go with us.
Gosh, we had a couple of German wives, they went to see Mimi, appealed to them, please, some of them would come to see me.
Of course, the sergeants did.
But for some reason, fortunately, they didn't go with us, but they went as replacements to Europe.
They shipped them out since they had to.
And that took a lot of bureaucratic work to get that authorized.
But they could still go as replacements in a pool, not necessarily in 18th Avenue, but somewhere else.
So it turned out all right.
But that was a difficult problem.
But we had one ship.
Oh, no, everybody's really high, including the draftee to go to Europe.
It's the best thing that could happen to them for their concern.
And it was because they could travel.
This was really an experience for a young man at gun expense.
And they liked the military because we had parades.
We tried to make it not drudgery, but they, it's their unit, you know.
And you even appeal to them and they respond to it.
We don't want an AWL.
And you can influence others.
If you find somebody that's

unhappy or thinking about that talk to him because he's reflecting on us you know we don't want any awl and we didn't have you know the first awls we had in europe we got replacement we had a bunch of characters two characters that came from the united states put down their barracks bag and took off took off for parents first awls we had in the in the unit and that was quite a few months actually
And the trip was very good.
We had a big ship for the battle group.
I flew, or we flew, ahead, so we'd be there in Bremerhaven to meet them.
The executive also had other people aboard the ship, so the trip was uneventful.
Fogged in at Bremerhaven, which is not unusual in Germany.
Where was the battle group stationed?
Near Mannheim, Germany.
And who is your superior?
His headquarters is in Bad Cross Mountain.
Let me see.
I can't think of the name.
During this, whatwere you with the NATO forces, part of the NATO forces?
Yeah.
How'd you get along inside the NATO structure?
Well, of course, we Go out on maneuvers and stuff like that?
Yeah.
We were a battle group there near Mannheim, real near where we cross the Rhine when I tell you about patent-directing traffic.
And out at Coleman Barracks, that's out of the suburb of Mannheim.
When we first arrived there, we had to undergo a test to convince the Army commander, Corps commander, that we were combat ready.
So we had that, as soon as we arrived, a three-day exercise, which we passed with a high mark.
And this was the first really test we had because the test we ran ourselves back in Fort Riley was not a three-day test.
It was about a day and a half.
So the only time we had that was necessary to complete our cycle for the BL.
But we did very well on that test.
And then we trained, of course.
We had training airs in the barge around the train.
And then we would go to
I met, I don't know his name here, Kaiselard, a big German, was a German, training here, and then he was a Frenchman now.
Trained there as a unit.
And then once a year you have a training test for three days.
Every month you have unannounced alerts.
And those are good tests because then you can measure how quickly that you can assemble a unit, get their equipment,
and move out to a dispersal area out of the barracks.
Sometime we would move there on to a training area, but most times you just acted as an all-air, and you reported the time it took you to close in.
If you called off, you returned back and cleaned your equipment the rest of that year.
One interesting side note, at least to me,
I told you these outstanding people that they weren't all from California.
I had from the University of Kentucky.
I had one of their basketball stars.
They didn't call him.
And I forget his name, too.
I can look it up.
I got him.
Clip him up there in the book up there.
Real fine young man from California.
I don't remember.
I think he played on the junior college.
We had five good basketball players.
We won the first division champion at Fort Riley.
Moved to Germany.
We were in eighth division.
And they had a delayed basketball season there because of the gyroscope.
And we won the eighth division championship.
You know, here in one year, they won two division championships.
That's fantastic.
That's really good.
Had a little guy, real short.
He was a Harlem grope-crawler type, you know.
Boy, he could dribble.
He was fast.
He weeded way down through that.
Finally get it to the tall University of Kentucky that he had an overhead loop shot.
As he fade away, you know.
How did the American troops get along with the German civilians?
Oh, now at this time, sure.
Excellent.
My wife Mimi was president of the German-American Women's Club.
And of course she was president of ours also in the 18th Infantry.
So we met, well she met with them, of course, but we had parties together.
They had plans, social functions, charity things, which all here are very active.
It was excellent.
The press was good to us.
We got good press, the German papers and Mannheim.
And the troops got along well in the community.
And by that time, sometimes there was resentment against the blacks.
But by that time, they had certain taverns which were receptive to blacks.
And these were the ones that you had a mixed marriage
would go to those because the resentment wasn't so much against the black as it was against that blonde German girl from there in the black.
They took the view of one of them, a real fine sergeant.
We had a boxer.
That's another 18th Infantry.
We had champion boxers.
I inherited those, but I took those over with us.
So we had champions in the division.
But they fought the Germans, too.
The Germans, of course, they had great boxers, you know, from the Shmelian days.
Only bad thing about that, we had to wear the headband, you know, so we wouldn't have injuries.
Of course, the Germans didn't.
Some of the Germans didn't understand.
But we always offered them.
They should wear them since we were wearing them.
But they'd usually say, no, we don't want to.
but some of the German people thought that, you know, not only was he black and big and good as far as a bargain, he was equipped with these guys, but he was protected.
So all of that, all the relationships in our battle group had the best record, disciplinary records.
Did it, really?
Yeah.
How can you account for that?
Well, because of these young men we had.
They just hired tight.
They weren't a cross-section of USA.
It was a select group.
And we had less demerits, I say disciplinary, no AWLs for a long time.
We had less maintenance, deadline vehicles.
And by all of the measurements, and we'd have our commander's conference, and the division headquarters always had all of these different
disciplinary items on the wall.
And we were always the lowest.
The highest was the paratroopers.
They had two battle groups, paratroopers.
Of course, they always proving their manhood and their fighting and drinking.
Sure.
They had the worst.
Do you think that
Your success at this job and the fact that the group is so outstanding, do you think that was one of the major reasons for your rise to generalship?
Yeah, because you have to be recommended.
Sure.
And so the division commander gave me a high-efficiency report and recommended me for General Lawson.
And that's another one the board meets.
If this individual had been recommended,
by a number of general officers.
And I don't mean by just a letter, because he wrote solicitors and said, would you write me a letter?
You know, he served with them over a period of time.
Well, then that has a weight.
But my next assignment probably contributed more or as much as this one.
And you stayed right in Germany then for the next two years.
Yeah.
Now, with the 7th United States Army Support Command in Europe, no.
What exactly were you doing in this?
See, that's in Mannheim also.
I bet you're sorry to give up your own personal command.
Oh, yeah.
We even had our own theme song.
And this was really popular with the Germans because the name of it was Happy Heiming.
And it was a composite of two German folk songs.
And the 18th Infantry had that for years, wasn't it?
And we had our own band, unauthorized band, and our own honor guard, unauthorized.
And how we did that, and I inherited this, so this is not my brilliant idea.
It got us in trouble in Europe.
One platoon of a unit.
We put all of the honor guard in one platoon, but one platoon was the honor guard.
And honor guard means we did all this drilling, you know, like the Marines do in Washington at the Marine.
All the fancy rifle stuff.
Plus, they really were honor guards.
And on field exercises, they provided the security for the headquarters.
Always, you've got to get it from somewhere, you know.
These were trains.
That's what you had to say.
That's what impressed us when we first
impressed the corps commander we got in Germany.
He came down, he called it a war camp, an operation, whatever.
And we had these two guys outside going.
And boy, they snapped to attention.
Of course, they could really make that rifle, you know, snap since they were training it.
And he stopped and double-taped, started talking to them, how long you been to Army and all that sort of thing.
Of course, they were just like everybody else.
They just had the skill.
And the band was another platoon of another unit.
And we had our own instruments.
And it was about a 12-piece band.
It wasn't very large, but they could play music.
But what was thrilling, even in the First Division, when the 18th Infantry would come, the band would stop whatever marks they were playing and play Happy Heine until we were all done.
So anything that was 18th Infantry, that was a song.
When we got to Europe, though, and these rifles, we had chrome rifles for the honor guard.
The old 03, the old rifles, all chromed up, chrome domed.
We'd gotten word that we weren't permitted to use those chrome rifles or couldn't use a band.
It was unauthorized.
So when we landed, automatically, the band came out in the honor guard with the colors off the ship first and lined up for everybody else.
And they were playing not only Happy Heine, but other pieces.
And the division commander came up to me and he said, you know, you're not supposed to have this.
I said, I know it.
morale building.
Everybody likes it.
He said, well, I tell you, I won't tell the Army Commander if you won't.
So we just never did show those things when they were out.
We still had our own parade battle groups.
Every chance we got a happy honey, we'd go out and do it.
So all those things would keep morale high.
Yeah.
That was top notch.
I'm telling you.
Just like a
an athletic group that's really fired up, you know.
And nearly all of them, I know all of them weren't that way, but the peer pressure kept a lot of them in line.
Sure.
You know, you jerks, if we go to do it this way, we get a long fine.
So 7th Army Support Command was the Army support, just like Division Trains was in the 1st Division.
This dealt with the entire 7th Army?
That's right, support.
So they're scattered and concerned all through Germany, just our headquarters in Mannheim.

So that job, and I was chief of staff at the time, and my job, besides being the chief of staff duties, I conducted inspections for the commanding general on all these quartermaster, engineer, chemical,
You just name it, all the facilities.
So that got me out of the office, which I wanted to do.
So I enjoyed that very much.
Now, the commanding general then was General Shervin.
And they put him there because he was an airborne general.
He commanded the 101st.
And General Bruce Clark wanted the support units to have the same standards that you have other ones.
soldierly quality, that is, in addition to their technical ability.
And Sherwin had done a good job in establishing this standard.
And he asked for me to be chief of staff since we live right up the street from him.
And I became his chief of staff.
Moved across the street and that caused a big problem because
